title: 107_s1572
content: The "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. Congress finds that in previous acts, it was declared that certain countries should be invited to become full NATO members to contribute to the security of the North Atlantic area. This includes the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO. In the European Security Act of 1998, Congress emphasized the importance of not limiting NATO enlargement to just Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia, but also considering other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe for membership. In the European Security Act of 1998, Congress emphasized the importance of NATO enlargement to include emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe. At the Madrid Summit in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO, with a declaration stating that Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria should also be invited upon meeting all criteria. At the Madrid Summit in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join NATO in the first round of enlargement. The NATO heads of state declared that further invitations would be extended to nations willing and able to meet membership obligations. At the Washington Summit in April 1999, NATO pledged to continue welcoming new members who uphold the principles of the Treaty and contribute to peace. In 1999, NATO pledged to continue welcoming new members who uphold the Treaty's principles and contribute to peace. A summit in Prague in late 2002 will decide on inviting additional democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join the Alliance. In May 2000, foreign ministers of several countries met in Vilnius, Lithuania. In May 2000, foreign ministers of emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership in the next round of enlargement. President George W. Bush also expressed support for Europe's new democracies in a speech in Warsaw, Poland in June 2001. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all of Europe's new democracies in a speech in Warsaw, Poland in June 2001, emphasizing the importance of security, freedom, and shared responsibilities within NATO. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized the importance of NATO remaining open to all of Europe's emerging democracies in a speech in Detroit, Michigan in 1996. He stated that no nation would be automatically excluded and no country outside NATO would have a veto, aiming to prevent a gray zone of insecurity from reemerging in Europe. Congress reaffirms its support for NATO enlargement as expressed in previous acts and declarations, endorsing the vision of further enlargement articulated by Presidents Bush and Clinton. They urge NATO allies to work towards realizing this vision at the Prague Summit in 2002. Designation of Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries already designated for assistance under related acts. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 designates Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria as eligible for assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. The President can also designate other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe for assistance under the same program. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for several countries including Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, and Romania is granted on a grant basis for fiscal year 2002. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for Bulgaria and Romania is granted on a grant basis. Amendment to Security Assistance Act of 2000 is made to strike certain paragraphs and redesignate others.
